Qst.Quest: if she will outline (1) the number of places in the Swinford Centre for persons with a mental handicap which remain to be occupied and (2) the length of time these have remained idle; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Aras Attracta, Swinford, was completed in 1985, and has a capacity for 186 adult places. The first resident was admitted on 7 November 1988 and 86 places have been commissioned to date. Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I have asked the health boards to supply the information requested and I will send it to the Deputy as soon as it is available.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the number of patient complaints received by her Department in (1) 1989 (2) 1990 and (3) 1991; in respect of each year's complaints the number of which she has furnished written reports to the complainant; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Records indicate that approximately 1,450 representations were made to the hospitals division of my Department in 1989, 1,150 in 1990 and 810 so far this year.
These figures must be seen in the context of over 500,000 patients being admitted to acute general hospitals in each of these years.

Where a complaint is made, it is my Department's policy to pursue this with the hospital concerned and, where appropriate, to review the outcome with my Department's professional advisers. In general, all such representations receive a reply.

Qst.Quest: the estimated level of spending by each health board on (a) legal fees and (b) medical liability insurance; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy is not readily available in the form requested. I am having the data prepared and will communicate it to the Deputy as soon as it is to hand.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that myasthenia gravis affects 160 people in Ireland; and whether her Department has any plans for support services or for research for the benefit of sufferers of this disease.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I am satisfied that the existing statutory schemes for general practitioner services, hospital services and drug cost refunds cater adequately for persons suffering from myasthenia gravis. Those with the condition are entitled to publicly funded health services in the normal way. They may apply for a medical card or, where they have Category II eligibility, they can avail themselves of the drugs refund scheme and the drug costs subsidisation scheme.

The Health Research Board, a statutory body under the responsibility of the Minister for Health, keeps itself informed of research developments in Ireland and abroad. While the board have no direct involvement in research into myasthenia gravis it will continue to keep in touch with developments in the area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Primary Teachers Special Leave.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the personnel policy thinking within his Department which provides for the authorisation of five days personal leave to primary teachers who, during their paid summer holidays, spend three weeks teaching in Coláistí Samhraidh na Gaeilge when they are on holiday pay; and if he will make a statement on the matter having regard to the fact that the five days personal leave amounts to a reduction, by one week, in the school year for pupils who are under the responsibility of such teachers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: The provision of extra personal leave for primary teachers who teach in Coláistí Samhraidh na Gaeilge during their summer holidays has been a long established policy within the Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disposal of Carysfort College.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: whether any letter of complaint was received from the Higher Education Authority about the lack of consultation or involvement in the purchase of Carysfort College by University College Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: Consultation with the Higher Education Authority did not arise, as the original recommendation concerning the use of Carysfort for educational purposes by UCD had resulted from the report of a working party chaired by the Chairman of the Higher Education Authority.

MainHeading.P: A letter was received from the Authority in February 1991 which indicated that while appreciating the sensitivity and necessity for confidentiality, and the time scale involved in the matter members felt they should have been consulted at the time.

The letter went on to indicate that the Authority was co-operating with UCD and with officers of the Department of Education in ensuring maximum use of the significant additional accommodation made available to the higher education sector for the benefit of students.

While noting the comments of the Authority, my Department indicated to officers of the Authority that the particular funds made available for the purchase of Carysfort were earmarked for that purpose and were additional to the 1991 capital allocation made available to the Higher Education Authority for distribution.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: if he will arrange for alternative leaving certificate mathematics sample papers to be made available for students in view of the fact that some schools have difficulty in obtaining these sufficiently far in advance of the examinations to be of benefit to the students with specific reference to the case of a person (details supplied) in Dublin 12.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: The sample papers to which the Deputy refers will be issued to all schools in the next few days.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Green Paper on Education.

Qst.Quest: whether any consultations or meetings were held between his Department and representatives of the Catholic hierarchy, on the proposed Green Paper on Education; if so, if he will outline the substance of these talks; and whether the issue of State subsidisation or the role of religion in education were discussed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: The Green Paper will be a discussion document designed to initiate a process of consultation and dialogue leading to a policy White Paper and later an Education Act. Accordingly no formal consultation or meetings have taken place on the Green Paper with any of the concerned interests in advance of its publication. In the course of the regular meetings, which take place on an ongoing basis between the Department and representatives of the various uconcerned interests, e.g. teachers, parents and school managers, groups would occassionally have expressed their general views in relation to the Green Paper. However the Department have not engaged in any detailed or specific discussions with any group except to emphasise that all interests will have ample opportunity to make their views known following the publications of the Green Paper.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Education Grant Application.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if a higher education grant or any other grant will be paid to a person (details supplied) in Limerick who has been deemed ineligible for such a grant as she did not have two honours in her Leaving Certificate.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: Inquiries have been made from the relevant local authorities and I regret to say that the person in question does not, under the current regulations, qualify for a higher education grant or for a vocational education committee scholarship.

MainHeading.P: However, as recently agreed in the Programme for Government, the amendment of the higher education grants scheme in a number of areas is being considered. The proposed amendments include regarding a mature student who secures a place in an approved course in a recognised third-level institution as satisfying the academic requirements for the award of a grant under the scheme. When a decision has been arrived at in relation to these proposals details of the scheme will be available from the local authorities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Limerick School Extension.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will meet a delegation from a parent committee from a school (details supplied) in County Limerick to discuss the extension to their school.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that plans to build an extension at a school (details supplied) in County Limerick have been seriously delayed; and if he will make a commitment to put the work up for tender this year with a view to having the new accommodation available early in 1992.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 139 and 140 together.

Tender documents have been completed for the proposed extension to the school in County Limerick referred to by the Deputy. The question of the invitation of tenders is being considered in the context of the 1992 budgetary situation and the many priorities and commitments. I am not therefore in a position to say, at this stage, when tenders will be invited for the project. Officials from my Department met with the school authorities recently and fully explained the situation to them.
Due to pressure of work I am not in a position, at this point, to meet a delegation from the school.

Qst.Quest: where uniforms used by the Defence Forces are manufactured; the source of supply; and (1) the total cost of supply of uniforms and (2) the quantity of uniforms supplied in 1990.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. V. Brady) Vincent Brady
Speaker.P: Uniforms supplied to the Defence Forces are manufactured in Ireland and the materials for the manufacture of uniforms are sourced in Ireland.

The total cost of items of clothing supplied to the Defence Forces in 1990 amounted to £3,819,000. These items included 5,000 service tunics, 11,000 service trousers, 12,000 working trousers, 21,000 service shirts and 5,000 working shirts, together with various quantities of combat suits, boots and headdress.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: the present status of the plan to decentralise part of Telecom Éireann to Waterford; when it is proposed to commence construction of the new offices there; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: As I indicated in my reply of 14 May 1991 (Official Report Volume 408, column 776) to a question on this subject, I am committed to the maximum possible amount of decentalisation. I have asked Telecom Éireann to have a further look at the possibility of finding staff for decentralisation and I understand from the company that any future opportunity to locate staff in Waterford will be considered very seriously. Meanwhile my Department are in contact with Telecom Éireann about the possibility of finding staff which might be decentralised to Waterford. The provision of office accommodation for any Telecom Éireann staff located in Waterford would be a matter for the company.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - State Bodies' Staff Uniforms.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: (1) the location where uniforms which are used by all State and semi-State bodies under the aegis of his Department are manufactured, (2) the source of supply and place of origin of the materials used for the uniforms, and (3) the total cost of supply and the quantity of uniforms supplied in 1990.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: Uniforms, which are only required by the messenger grade in my Department are supplied by the Office of Public Works. I understand that the materials used for the uniforms are provided by an Irish weaving company and the uniforms are made up by an Irish clothing manufacturer.
The total cost of uniform items purchased by my Department in 1990 was just under £124.
I have no function in relation to the provision of uniforms for the staff of semi-State bodies under the aegis of my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Level Crossing Barriers.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: the number of automatic level crossing barriers installed, per county, in each of the last three years; and his views on whether these automatic barriers are much safer for road users than the outdated unmanned crossings.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: I have been informed by the Chairman of CIE that automatic half barriers were installed at Newberry East level crossing, County Cork in 1989 and at Oranmore level crossing, County Galway in 1991. These crossings were previously gated level crossings operated by a crossing keeper.

In addition to these automatic barriers, semi-automatic barriers were installed at Skehacraeggaun and at Dock Road, County Limerick. These crossings are both situated on the Limerick Cement factory siding.

MainHeading.P: I am satisfied that automatic level crossings operating in conjunction with associated warning lights, road traffic signs and markings are safer for road users than older gated crossings.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Westmeath Level Crossing.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself in relation to the safety of road users at level crossing No. 99 at Torrydonnellan, County Westmeath on the Dublin-Athlone railway line where (1) the track has been raised by approximately three feet, (2) the remade approach roads are dangerous because of a loose gravel surface, (3) access gates are 8' 9" wide and are unsuitable for access by farm machinery, (4) there are approximately 24 trains using the line daily and (5) five families must cross here regularly to gain access to their houses; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: The Chairman of CIE has informed me that the track at Torrydonnellan accommodation crossing on the Dublin-Athlone railway was raised approximately 8" during track renewal work in 1990.

I understand that following the track renewal the road approaches to the crosssing were improved by Westmeath County Council to compensate for the track lift. The width of the crossing surface was also increased to meet the demands of road users. I am advised that when the track structure settles early in the New Year it is proposed to install a precast concrete surface, which is on order at present.
Manned attendance is not provided at the level crossing and users have responsibility for opening and closing the gates and for the safe use of the crossing.
